GLSV: Graphics library stereo vision for OpenGL

  • S. Martín1,
  • J. Suárez1,
  • R. Orea1,
  • R. Rubio1 &
  • R. Gallego1 

Virtual Reality volume 13, pages51–57(2009)Cite this article

  • 244 Accesses

  • 4 Citations

  • 0 Altmetric

Abstract

This work proposes the development of an auxiliary library for use with OpenGL, to facilitate the creation of graphic applications incorporating stereoscopic representation. This library, christened graphics library stereo vision (GLSV), is designed to remove all calculations involving knowledge of stereo vision theory from the task performed by the programmer without the latter having to change the way he/she has been working with the OpenGL library. The GLSV is distributed under the terms of the GNU Library General Public License agreement.

Introduction

Man’s interest in representing the three-dimensional reality surrounding us by means of a two-dimensional projection has remained unchanging through the ages. The irruption of computers in the second half of the XX century brought about an unprecedented revolution in the area of graphic representation. Stereovision techniques (StereoGraphics Corporation 1999) have been impelled by this technological impulse.

For the development of graphic applications, the programmer normally has recourse to graphic programming libraries, also known as graphic APIs (API: Application Programming Interface).

There are a large number of graphic libraries: OpenGL, Direct3D, GKS, PHIGS, PEX, etc. OpenGL (OpenGL Architecture Review Board, http://www.opengl.org, 2005) and DirectX are currently the most widely used. However, there are two essential differences between them: whereas Direct3D is a proprietary library of Microsoft, designed exclusively for the development of applications within the Windows environment, OpenGL is a freeware standard for the development of multiplatform applications. Applications developed using this library can run on any system, such as Unix®, Linux, Windows 95/98/2000/NT, Mac OS, OS/2, etc. Furthermore, the final users and independent software sellers do not require any licence for the use of OpenGL.

These two characteristics: free standard and multiplatform nature, are responsible for OpenGL continuing to be the reference for graphic application programmers after more than 14 years.

Generally, programmers use OpenGL in combination with other supplementary APIs in order to generalize functions common to most developers. Thus, for example, the GLU (OpenGL Utility) library simplifies the programmer’s work by defining the scenario to be displayed.

Nowadays there are a great number of graphics applications offering the possibility of three-dimensional representation (3D). The user can display a conical projection on the computer screen, which enhances spatial understanding of the designs. Virtual representations of great realism can be obtained through the addition to the conical projection of algorithms for overlapping and the suppression of hidden lines, lighting effects and surface texturing.

Nevertheless, in these 3D representation systems, the image obtained is unique, whereas human vision is binocular, stereoscopic. We perceive reality through two images, the result of two conical projections in which the view point is very slightly different. The brain integrates the two images to form a single representation of reality, deducing the distance of the objects forming it from the disparity between the two images.

The problem involved in generating a stereo image in the computer affects not only the computer program, but also the display devices. Stereo display devices in PCs have evolved from the simple anaglyphic glasses to systems of shutter glasses, lenticular filters, alternative polarizing screens, auto-stereo monitors and head mounted displays.

Development of 3D graphics using OpenGL

OpenGL has been conceived for the creation of graphic contents in both orthogonal and conical projections. In order to recreate a three-dimensional environment using photo-realism techniques, the conical projection system must be used, as it is the one that most faithfully represents the image captured by the human eye or photographic objectives (Foley et al. 1997).

OpenGL offers a series of functions that facilitate the programmer’s work to achieve a conical projection. In order to define the position of the camera, we can use the gluLookAt function in the GLU auxiliary library (OpenGL Architecture Review Board 1997).

The need to limit calculations in any computer system makes it necessary to define a display volume, so that only the graphic objects included in it are projected (see Fig. 1). OpenGL defines this volume as a pyramid frustum with a rectangular base. The base of the pyramid frustum will pertain to the so-called Far plane, which represents the background of the scene. The upper face of the pyramid frustum will correspond to the Near plane. This plane, besides restricting the volume displayed within its area nearest the camera, coincides with projection plane π in OpenGL.

Apparently, this coincidence is not important: projection plane π represents the plane on which the computer monitor or projection screen is located, and the reality to be represented should be behind it. However, as we should see later, this necessary coincidence of projection plane π with the Near plane merits more detailed consideration in the case of stereo projections.

OpenGL contains a function glFrustum, which allows the volume displayed to be defined. The gluPerspective function of the GLU auxiliary library provides an alternative to glFrustum.

The gluPerspective function reduces the parameters required from six to four, because it assumes that the window of the scene is symmetrically centred around the point of intersection between visual v and the Near plane. It is not usual to need windows that are asymmetrical with regard to visual v; however, as we see below, it is the case with stereo projection.

Development of stereo graphics using OpenGL

Implementation of stereo projection in OpenGL

The main difference between a monoscopic and stereoscopic projection is that in the latter case there is not just one view point V from which the scene is observed, but two, one for each eye (Akka 1998; Carrozzo and Lacquaniti 1997; Hodges and Davis 1993; Southard 1992). These points, which we shall call V l (left eye) and V r (right eye), are separated from each other by a given distance, called interaxial distance, d. This distance should be approximately 6 cm in order to faithfully reproduce human vision.

The positioning of the cameras in OpenGL for a stereo projection does not entail any difficulty. View points V l and V r will be defined using function gluLookAt described previously.

The definition of the volumes displayed requires more careful analysis. In the first place, it can be deduced from the geometrical interpretation of the stereo projection that the projection window is not symmetrical to the visual from either V l or V r, (v l and v r, ). Therefore, the glFrustum function must not be used to define either of the displayed volumes (neither must gluPerspective). One solution is shown in the Fig. 2 (Bourke 1999).

Unfortunately, this solution does not allow objects located in front of projection plane π to be represented. This is due to the fact that projection plane π is identified with the Near plane in OpenGL. Any object between the observer and plane π is outside the volume displayed and is not represented.

However, the effect of representing objects floating in front of the monitor or the projection screen is much used in stereo projections and, therefore, an adequate solution for this problem has to be found using OpenGL.

For this purpose, we shall initially simply ignore the fact that in OpenGL projection plane π and the Near plane must coincide. The volumes displayed would then be defined as shown in the Fig. 3.

The glFrustum allows us to perfectly define both volumes, but the projection will be made on a Near window, defined on the Near plane, and not on the projection window, defined in projection plane π. Fortunately, it is easy to demonstrate geometrically that the difference between the two projections is merely a scaling operation.

Such scaling can be implemented in OpenGL using the glViewport function (see Fig. 4). This function defines the size, in pixels, of the image that is sent to the display device. Four parameters are required for this purpose. The first two represent the x and y coordinates of the bottom left corner of the image, referred to the coordinate system of the graphic device. The other two represent the width and height of the image.

The glViewport function allows the Near window, defined in OpenGL units of space, to be converted into a window on the graphic device, which we may call graphic window and which will, initially, be measured in pixels, although its physical dimension can be calculated. Thus, we can select this graphic window so that its physical dimensions are coherent with the dimensions in OpenGL space of the projection window.

This means that we intended to make a scaling operation between the Near window and the projection window, by means of an instruction that OpenGL does not provide, followed by a final transformation of the result towards a graphic window located on the display device, by means of the glViewport function. However, what we in fact do is to make a single transformation that includes both operations, from the Near window to the graphic window, using glViewport.

This ratio between OpenGL space and real dimensions must be common for all the items in the scene. Thus, the same ratio must be applied between the interaxial distance and the real value of the interocular distance; between the view point V to projection plane π distance and the distance separating the user from the monitor or the projection screen.

Influence of the computer system

Once the geometrical problems involved in the creation of stereo scenes have been solved, it is necessary to briefly consider the difficulties associated with the transmission of the image to the display device.

In a computer system, the graphic card driver is the core of any stereo development, as it creates the connection between the stereo hardware and the development software.

The programmer may face two different situations when generating a stereogram: the video card may belong to the quad buffer category or to the double buffer category.

With quad technology video cards, the two images that define the stereogram are transmitted separately, through two independent communication channels. This is the “dual stream” format. Using in OpenGL glGetBoolean and the GL_STEREO attribute the programmer can query if the current display configuration permits the creation of stereo quad-buffered windows. The quad video cards have four memory zones or buffers. While two of them, called left-front buffer and right-front buffer, contain the pair of images being displayed on the device, the following scene to be displayed is created on the other two, called left-back buffer and right-back buffer. The driver adapts this double stream of information to the display device chosen.

In a second category—the double buffer technology video cards—both images of the stereo pair are transmitted via a single communication channel. The format used is the so-called alternated pages.

The alternated pages format can be used in two different ways. The first way consists of alternatively generating the two images that define the stereogram. We shall call this the alternated image format. While the front buffer contains the image that is being displayed on the device, for example the left image, the right image of the pair is created in the back buffer. This system allows a high resolution in shutter glasses-type devices or head mounted displays. However, the performance of the video card diminishes. Regardless of whether events that modify scene occur or not, the left and right views have to be continuously and alternately recreated, and synchronized with the refresh speed of the display device.

The alternated pages format has traditionally been used in a different way. Traditionally, the two images that define the stereogram are transmitted together as a single image. There are many possible formats that allow the stereogram to be combined in a single image: anaglyph, col interlaced, row interlaced, above/below, side by side (Lipton 1997b). Depending on the display device, these formats can be used directly. It is always possible to transform one format into another, using interpolated software. In any case, while the front buffer contains, for example, the anaglyph corresponding to an instant of time t, which is displayed on the device, the back buffer receives the anaglyph corresponding to instant t + 1. The loss of resolution of the stereogram, inherent to these formats, is compensated, from the economic point of view, by the lower level of technical sophistication required of the video card.

From the point of view of the programmer using OpenGL, the use of one format or the other conditions the design of the code. Pseudo-codes for the generation of a stereo pair are shown below as an example for anaglyph, alternated pages and dual stream formats. The obvious differences between the three examples highlight the need for the programmer to rigorously manage the format or work method.

Alternated pages: Anaglyph (double buffer)

  • Initialise the buffer

  • Define the scene for the left view

  • Activate filter for left image (for example, cyan)

  • Transmit the scene to the back buffer

  • Deactivate the filter for the left view

  • Define the scene for the right view

  • Activate filter for right image (for example, red)

  • Transmit the scene to the back buffer

  • Deactivate the filter for the right view

  • Exchange buffers

Alternated pages: Alternated images (double buffer)

  • Initialise the back buffer

  • If the left view is active

  • Define the scene for the left view

  • Transmit the scene to the back buffer

  • Ifnot

  • Define the scene for the right view

  • Transmit the scene to the back buffer

  • Endif

  • Exchange buffers

Dual Stream (quad buffer)

  • Initialise left back buffer and right back buffer

  • Define the scene for the left view

  • Transmit the scene for left view to the left back buffer

  • Define the scene for right view

  • Transmit the scene for right view to the right back buffer

  • Exchange buffers

Proposal for an auxiliary OpenGL library: GLSV

As can be deduced from the foregoing sections, the OpenGL structure allows the creation of stereo contents. However, any programmer who wishes to develop these contents has to fully understand the rules governing stereoscopy which, besides entailing a considerable additional effort, is a possible source of errors.

Some manufacturers, both graphic card and display device manufacturers, have developed drivers with stereo functions (NVidia Corporation http://www.nvidia.com, 2005). These drivers generate two or even more cameras from a single scene defined in OpenGL. The result is a stereogram that can be displayed in the various devices that support the driver in question (shutter glasses, auto-stereo monitors, etc.). Obviously, offering these drivers with stereo functions represents a competitive advantage of the first order for hardware manufacturers. The problem is that these drivers are not multiplatform and the programmer has not the total control of the parameters associated with the stereo nature of the scene.

From this we can deduce the advantage of defining an auxiliary library that eliminates the need for the programmer to make any calculations requiring mastery of the theory of stereo vision. It would be desirable that the use of such a library does not oblige the programmer to understand a new set of functions, or change the way of developing applications with OpenGL. Furthermore, the distribution under the terms of a free software license like GNU would be desirable.

These requirements form the basis for the design of the auxiliary GLSV library (Graphics Library Stereo Vision) developed by the I 3 G research group, Investigación e Innovación en Ingeniería Gráfica (Research and Innovation in Graphic Engineering) at Oviedo University (http://www.ideascad.es). To the above requirements must be added others associated with two basic concepts: the administration of the scene components and control of the stereo format.

The first concept, the administration of scene components, should give rise to a series of functions that basically allow:

  • The definition of the position of the cameras

  • The definition of the volume of the stereo display

The second concept, the control of the stereo format, requires the definition of another series of functions that allow:

  • Exchange between stereo vision formats implemented in the program at any moment of its execution: dual stream, alternated pages, anaglyph, etc.

  • The control of the left, right and central cameras.

    • Definition of the active camera

    • Enquiries as to the active camera

    • Switching of the active camera (between left and right)

  • The management of variables associated with a specific stereo format. For example, in the case of an anaglyph format:

    • The choice of the type of glasses: red/blue, red/cyan, etc.

    • The activation/deactivation of the colour filter

Functions implemented in GLSV

At present, the functions implemented in the GLSV library for the administration of scene components are glsvLookAt and glsvPerspective. The glsvLookAt function is similar to the gluLookAt function. It receives ten variables as parameters, one more than its homonym. The first three define the coordinates of the observer in the reference system, i.e., the view point of the observer (V o ). The following three represent the coordinates of any point belonging to the visual traced from the observer (v o ). The following three variables define the vertical orientation of the cameras in space (common for both). Finally, glsvLookAt requires a tenth variable, the interaxial distance or separation between the cameras.

The glsvPerspective function has a direct link with its homonym gluPerspective. In this case, six parameters are required. The first four coincide with those of gluPerspective and define the opening of the display volume pyramid, the aspect ratio of the projection window, and the distances from observer V o to the Near and Far planes. The last two variables define the distance V o to the projection plane π and the interaxial distance.

With regard to stereo format control, the functions currently implemented in GLSV to change between stereo vision formats are glsvSetStereoMode and glsvGetStereoMode. The former establishes the desired format, while the latter provides information about the format currently selected. To date, the dual stream, alternated pages-alternated images and alternated pages – anaglyph formats have been implemented in GLSV .

The following functions: glsvSetActiveEye, glsvGetActiveeye and glsvSwapEye have been implemented for camera management. The first function allows the active camera to be established, while the second allows an enquiry as to which camera is active. Three different cameras are defined: left and right, for stereo projections, and central, when a monoscopic projection from the observer position V o is required. The glsvSwapEye function allows the active camera to be switched between the left and right options.

Several functions associated with the anaglyph format: glsvAnaglyphSetGlasses and glsvActiveAnaglyphFiltered have been implemented to manage variables associated with this specific stereo format. The first function, glsvAnaglyphSetGlasses, receives as a parameter a variable defining the type of anaglyph glasses to be used: red/blue, red/green, red/cyan, blue/red, green/red and cyan/red. The glsvActiveAnaglyphFiltered function activates/deactivates a colour mask, depending on the type of glasses selected and the camera that is active at that time.

There have been defined also two functions associated with the interlaced format: glsvInterlacedMask and glsvInterlacedFiltered. The first function, glsvInterlacedMask, creates a row interlaced mask. The second function, glsvInterlacedFiltered activates/deactivates that mask, depending on the camera that is active at that time.

Proposed future functionality of GLSV

To date, the following stereo formats: dual stream, alternated pages-alternated images, alternated pages-anaglyph and alternated pages-row interlaced have implemented in GLSV.

The implementation of the above-below, side-by-side and column-interlaced formats is foreseen and has not difficulty. The side-by-side format will be specially useful for HMDs with single-surface display.

Support for head-tracked stereo with single-surface displays (e.g., head-tracked user in front of stereo CRT or LCD or projection screen) implies the definition of a new function for the administration of scene components, glsvFustrum. It has a direct link with its homonym glFustrum, because it must be used when the assumption that the user’s head is centered in front of the display is false.

The GLSV has been designed to facilitate the creation of graphic applications incorporating stereoscopic representation based on two views. Nevertheless, the possibility of implementing other formats, particularly those associated with the new auto-stereo monitors in which eight or more views are needed, must be studied.

Finally, it has been observed that the alternated image format works only if the card does not miss frames. That is, if the scene is simple enough to be rendered within a single frame time. Otherwise, it is necessary to manually resynchronize the shutter glasses switching of the active camera (between left and right) with glsvSwapEye. It would be interesting to automatically measure the time between buffer swaps and try to recover in situations where swaps are missed. There are methods for that however, such as blue-line sync.

Conclusions

The creation of stereo graphs using OpenGL requires the programmer to have a profound knowledge of the geometrical bases of stereo projection. The GLSV, Graphics Library Stereo Vision, auxiliary library removes this problem for the programmer, without making it necessary to change the way he/she has been working with the OpenGL library, as the functions introduced are equivalent in all aspects.

Compared to other alternatives, such as the use of drivers with stereo capability, the GLSV library allows the programmer to maintain full control over the parameters defining the composition of the stereo scene. Moreover, as it is directly based on the OpenGL standard, it inherits the advantages of the latter, particularly its independence from the operating system chosen and its portability on any hardware device with OpenGL support. The GLSV library is distributed under the terms of the GNU Library General Public License agreement.
